author: ajsutton
content: I will say as a client implementer, that getting a spec which clearly shows the difference between forks is absolutely invaluable. If the Altair spec had been completely stand alone it would have been nearly impossible to find all the differences. We the changes prior to launch we had to diff the different versions of the spec and work through every little change which then makes it very difficult to ever rearrange the spec because that just makes everything appear changed in the diffs.

author: ajsutton
content: ‚òùÔ∏è Yep, that.  If you never do any reformatting or rearranging, then having to complete specs that you do a `git diff` type thing on is ok, but you can't ever reformat or rearrange things without doing the exact same thing to all versions so the diffs still work.  Essentially you're now maintaining a full spec for each fork (which is a lot of duplication) *and* have to carefully track the meta-version generated by diffing them.

author: ajsutton
content:
And for the record, I was part of the team that helped build Besu and it actually worked quite well to just start by implementing Frontier, then layer the next fork on top of that, then the next etc.  So a spec like the eth2 specs still works really well for that.

I can definitely see that for people who just want to consult the spec for a specific topic that having the latest version as a complete spec makes life a lot easier.  So in my ideal world I'd have a diff based spec for each fork but also maintain a collapsed version for the latest fork - which funnily enough is pretty much what we have for eth1 with EIPs and the yellow paper, I'd just like the EIPs to be easier to find and the yellow paper more readable and up to date.
